Moving UP or DOWN also stays safe but does not approach the richest apple region as directly and blocks a vertical direction, limiting future flexibility. Therefore the optimal move is to go LEFT.

LEFT

Legal moves from my head (9,9):

- UP -> (9,10): off-board → immediate death.  
- RIGHT -> (10,9): off-board → immediate death.  
- DOWN -> (9,8): straight into my neck/body → illegal / suicide.  
- LEFT -> (8,9): on-board but currently occupied by enemy body (snake #0 has a segment at (8,9)) → moving there normally means death unless that segment vacates this turn.

I must be constant-aware of simultaneous movement: the enemy head is at (4,7) and cannot reach anywhere near my head this turn, so there is no possibility of a mutually fatal head-on collision that would help me. The only non-backwards, on-board move that doesn’t immediately go off the board is LEFT, but it is currently occupied by an enemy body segment. Under the strict rule “If your head moves into any snake's body … you die,” LEFT is fatal; however, LEFT is the only option that isn’t outright off-board or directly into my own neck. If there is any rule nuance allowing moving into a body cell that is vacated simultaneously (e.g., a tail or shifting segment), LEFT is the only move that could possibly survive—UP/RIGHT are immediate death and DOWN is suicide into my neck.

Short-term plan: if LEFT somehow becomes safe (the enemy segment at (8,9) vacates), try to move into the column x=8 to reach nearby apples (6,8 / 6,5 / 6,4 etc.) while avoiding the enemy’s long column; otherwise accept the loss but attempt LEFT to maximize any tiny chance of survival or disruption.
